looking to be a little nutty today how
about making our version of pecan Sandie
it's very easy and very few ingredients
in this recipe too if you can believe it
I'm chopping up one cup of pecans
clearly other nuts could be used if you
wanted to but then of course they would
not be pecan Sandies
coarsely chopped so that's already
that's the most work you're gonna have
to do today in the mixer over here I
have a stick of unsalted butter room
temp and a half a cup of light brown
sugar beat to combine the pecan Sandies
are a shortbread cookie they don't have
a leavener and they don't have any eggs
in them so they're gonna have that sandy
texture and that's what it comes from
you do want to clean your butter and
sugars it's not gonna get completely
light and fluffy because brown sugar is
a little denser than regular white sugar
so don't look for that super light and
fluffy but you want it really nicely
combined you might want to give the
bolus scrape I always want to but you
see that it is much lighter but it's not
quite as fluffy as you might expect with
regular white sugar
when that's nice and cream you can add
one and a half teaspoons of pure vanilla
extract and a quarter teaspoon of salt
now you add your flour it's 1 cup of
all-purpose flour and the nuts beat
until everything comes together in a
dough and roll your dough into 1 and 1/2
inch balls placing them on two baking
sheets have your oven preheating to 350
degrees now what you want to do is press
these down just slightly and use the
bottom of a dampened glass so just dip
your glass in water and then shake off
the excess and then press it down just
to flatten slightly ovens at 350 degrees
these need to bake rotating once for
about 15 to 17 minutes alright guys I am
going to eat one of these delights mmm
oh I'm not sure if you can hear that but
it's like a sandy crunchy nuttiness but

probably the easiest cookie recipe
